thread.title: ODU men, women picked second in Conference USA basketball coaches' polls
thread.title_full: ODU men, women picked second in Conference USA basketball coaches' polls

title: ODU men, women picked second in Conference USA basketball coaches' polls
text:
ODU men, women picked second in Conference USA basketball coaches' polls Compiled by Daily Press 
COLLEGES: 
Men’s basketball: 
Coming off a National Invitation Tournament semifinal showing, Old Dominion was chosen second to defending tournament champion Alabama Birmingham in Conference USA’s coaches’ poll. 
UAB returns all five starters, while ODU will rely on 2014-15 C-USA Newcomer of the Year Trey Freeman at guard. 
Women’s basketball: 
After posting 21 wins last season and advancing to the WNIT second round, the Old Dominion Lady Monarchs were picked second in the Conference USA coaches’ poll. The Middle Tennessee Blue Raiders were selected as the favorites. 
Last season’s C-USA Newcomer of the Year, Jennie Simms, a preseason All-C-USA selection, will lead ODU, which placed second in the preseason poll with four first-place votes following its run in the C-USA tournament. Simms emerged as one of the dominant guards in the league. 
Football: 
Maryland is likely to fire head coach Randy Edsall by the conclusion of Saturday’s game against No. 1 Ohio State, according to a report from Inside Maryland Sports’ Jeff Ermann. ... 
The Central Intercollegiate Athletic Association was made aware of an alleged violation related to the eligibility of a Bowie State player, who has not been publicly identified. The CIAA office is working with Bowie State (4-1, 2-0 CIAA) during its fact-finding process. Upon completion of the investigation, the CIAA will respond. 
Women’s soccer: 
No. 5 Virginia Tech (12-1-1, 4-1 Atlantic Coast Conference) defeated Wake Forest 3-1 as Murielle Tiernan scored two first-half goals. ... 
No. 6 Virginia (9-1-1, 3-1 ACC) beat No. 9 Clemson 2-0, thanks to second-half goals by the visitors' Brittany Ratcliffe -- her first of the season -- and Morgan Reuther. 
Field hockey: 
Lisa Murphy scored the winning goal with just more than five minutes left in overtime to lead Christopher Newport (8-1, 2-0 Capital Athletic Conference), 14th in Division III, to a 3-2 win at St. Mary’s (Md.). 
Brittan Muir, who assisted on Murphy’s score, added a goal and finished with two assists for the Captains. 
Men's tennis: 
Virginia Tech, which placed a school-record four players in the Intercollegiate Tennis Association's All-American Championships in Tulsa, Okla., saw all of them fall into the consolation bracket with competitive first-round defeats. 
Edoardo Tessaro, who joined Joao Monteiro as Hokies who advanced into the draw of 64 via the qualifying bracket, retired while trailing 2-6, 7-5, 3-0 to Ohio State's Chris Diaz. 
Monteiro pressed No. 2 seed Nicolas Alvarez of Duke but lost 6-4, 4-6, 6-3. Tech's Andreas Bjerrehus fell 6-2, 7-6 (14-12) to No. 6 seed Roberto Cid of South Florida, and the Hokies' Amerigo Contini lost 7-6 (7-2), 3-6, 7-6 (7-4) to Illinois' Aron Hiltzik. 
Virginia's only player in the round of 64 is No. 3 seed Thai-Son Kwiatkowski. He won 6-4, 6-2 against San Diego's Filip Vittek. 
No Hokies were in the doubles draw, the Kwiatkowski and Mac Styslinger -- seeded in the 5-8 group -- won 6-3, 6-3 in the first round against Tulsa's Carlos Bautista and Juan Matias Gonzalez. 
Women's tennis: 
Virginia seniors went 1-1 in the first main-draw round of the Riviera/ITA All-American Championships in Pacific Palisades, Calif. 
Danielle Collins, the 2014 NCAA singles champ, won 6-0, 6-2 against Giuliana Olmos of Southern California to earn a berth against left-hander Caroline Doyle of Stanford. 
U.Va.'s Julia Elbaba fell 3-6, 6-4, 6-2 to Sinead Lohan of Miami and will play a fellow ACC competitor for the second day in a row, this time in the consolation draw: Lexi Borr of Boston College.
